interlinear-text.item: ELA ʐɨ qəsoid mani (The Meaning of My Ode) -

phrase.item: In order for our language not to disappear, you preserve it by filming. I write songs in our language in order to save it.
I also have handwritten a book, which has approximately 270 to 300 songs in it,
but I haven't found anyone who can type and publish it.
So I have many songs in Wakhi.

For instance, from the ode, in this busy world, as you see around you, there are different religions and faiths, and what [I sang in the ode] is: "Oh, beloved Mawla [Aga Khan], guide us along the right path so that our young people, and everybody in general, don't get lost.
All my hope is that you, Mawla, that you can guide and protect us.
In this busy life, all my hopes are in you, Mawla. I am a blind creator and all my hopes are you, Mawla."
That means I am still not aware of Mawla's mysteries.
Because, recently we were able to see our Mawla physically
and we are still discovering everything.

Then — "the people of the world are holding onto the earth, but there is nobody who could hold his faith." That means, there are people in this world who are holding onto earth [wealth], but there is no one who is holding [practicing] his [kind of] faith.
Right?
There are many people who are not aware of their own faith.
Then I repeated again, "O beloved Mawla, guide everyone not just to go after material life." Right?
Those who have taken the money path.
But there are only few who are into their faith.
That's all!
We have another friend,
who is not here currently, called Qurbonsho. He writes beautiful [songs].
Also, there is another guy, Mirali from Zugvand.
Who else? Ikrom, another guy, a new, young student, he also started writing songs and odes in our language.
As you mentioned, very few of our odes and songs are written down in books, so if we don't work on it, nothing will be left for the next generation.
We are hoping and willing to have books, and for odes to be sung in our language.
